column1: Thank you for contacting Netwrix Technical Support.
My name is Artem, I will be assisting you with this ticket.
To ensure efficient troubleshooting and resolve your issue confidently I need additional information from you.
Please, answer these questions and provide more details:

column2: You are currently experiencing 90% RAM utilization on the SQL server for for Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor). Is that correct?
Do you have a dedicated/separate SQL server for Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor) database? Or application and SQL server are located on the same machine?
How much RAM and CPU resources does your SQL server have?
Why 90% RAM usage on SQL server is unexpected to you? Was RAM usage lower previously?
If the RAM usage was different before - what has changed in the Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor) application? Did you configure a new job/solution recently?

I need build version information of your Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor) application. Run this command from administrative PowerShell and share output where build version information is visible:

column1: To continue, according to our SQL server System requirements for Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor) the RAM and CPU usage on SQL server depends on what jobs and solutions are in use.
Please, follow this link to have a closer look at SQL server system requirements to understand what is the expected RAM and CPU usage on SQL server depending on what jobs you have configured:
The server requirements include one of the following SQL Server versions:

column2: SQL Server 2016 through SQL Server 2022
Azure SQL Managed Instances

column1: Additionally the server must meet this requirement:

column2: US English language installation

column1: These are dependent upon the size of the target environment. See the following topics for additional:

column1: 1.  You are currently experiencing 90% RAM utilization on the SQL server for for Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor). Is that correct? Yes
2.  Do you have a dedicated/separate SQL server for Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor) database? Or application and SQL server are located on the same machine? Separate database server
3.  How much RAM and CPU resources does your SQL server have? 8 cores and 36GB RAM
4.  Why 90% RAM usage on SQL server is unexpected to you? Was RAM usage lower previously? yes

5.  If the RAM usage was different before - what has changed in the Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor) application? Did you configure a new job/solution recently? No but recently lots of jobs were enabled where it was disabled previously

Thank you for contacting Netwrix Technical Support.
My name is Artem, I will be assisting you with this ticket.
To ensure efficient troubleshooting and resolve your issue confidently I need additional information from you.
Please, answer these questions and provide more details:
1.  You are currently experiencing 90% RAM utilization on the SQL server for for Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor). Is that correct?
2.  Do you have a dedicated/separate SQL server for Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor) database? Or application and SQL server are located on the same machine?
3.  How much RAM and CPU resources does your SQL server have?
4.  Why 90% RAM usage on SQL server is unexpected to you? Was RAM usage lower previously?
5.  If the RAM usage was different before - what has changed in the Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor) application? Did you configure a new job/solution recently?

6.  I need build version information of your Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor) application. Run this command from administrative PowerShell and share output where build version information is visible:
To continue, according to our SQL server System requirements for Netwrix Access Analyzer (Enterprise Auditor) the RAM and CPU usage on SQL server depends on what jobs and solutions are in use.
Please, follow this link to have a closer look at SQL server system requirements to understand what is the expected RAM and CPU usage on SQL server depending on what jobs you have configured:
The server requirements include one of the following SQL Server versions:
Additionally the server must meet this requirement:
These are dependent upon the size of the target environment. See the following topics for additional:

*   Active Directory Solution Requirements on the SQL Server<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/AccessAnalyzer_12.0/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Solutions/ActiveDirectory.htm#Active2>

*   Active Directory Permissions Analyzer Solution Requirements on the SQL Server<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/AccessAnalyzer_12.0/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Solutions/ActiveDirectoryPermissionsAnalyzer.htm#Active2>
*   AWS Solution Requirements on the SQL Server<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/AccessAnalyzer_12.0/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Solutions/AWS.htm#Solution>
*   Box Solution Requirements on the SQL Server<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/AccessAnalyzer_12.0/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Solutions/Box.htm#Box2>
*   Databases Solution Requirements on the SQL Server<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/AccessAnalyzer_12.0/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Solutions/Databases.htm#Database2>
*   Entra ID Solution Requirements on the SQL Server<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/AccessAnalyzer_12.0/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Solutions/EntraID.htm#Entra2>
*   Exchange Solution Requirements on the SQL Server<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/AccessAnalyzer_12.0/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Solutions/Exchange.htm#Exchange2>
*   File System Solution Requirements on the SQL Server<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/AccessAnalyzer_12.0/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Solutions/FileSystem.htm#File2>
*   SharePoint Solution Requirements on the SQL Server<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/AccessAnalyzer_12.0/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Solutions/SharePoint.htm#SharePoi2>
*   Unix Solution Requirements on the SQL Server<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/AccessAnalyzer_12.0/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Solutions/Unix.htm#Unix2>
*   Windows Solution Requirements on the SQL Server<https://helpcenter.netwrix.com/bundle/AccessAnalyzer_12.0/page/Content/EnterpriseAuditor/Requirements/Solutions/Windows.htm#Windows2>

Thank you for sharing this information.

You mentioned that recently some jobs were enabled that were previously in disabled status. As such, increase in RAM consumption is expected because additional jobs started running and thus more RAM is needed on SQL server.
Which jobs exactly were enabled recently? Which jobs exactly are currently running on your Netwrix Access Analyzer (formerly Enterprise Auditor) server?

I wanted to check in regarding your support ticket 00442226. We haven't heard from you in a while, and I just wanted to see if you still need assistance with this issue.
If you're still experiencing problems or have any updates to share, please let me know. If the issue has been resolved, I can go ahead and close the ticket on my end.

ref:!00D70091pB.!500Qk0O6k3y:ref","RE: Netwrix Support Ticket #442226 - ref:_00D7091pB._500Q000O6k3y:ref - RE: 00442226 - Database memory utilization","o_alkaabi@qatarenergy.qa","Ohoud Hamad Kh Al-Kaabi","techsupport@netwrix.com","","","true","2025-04-27T05:34:37.000Z","true"
Thank you for your time on our meeting today.
I am glad that we had a closer look at the issue today together with your team.
The following is a recap of what we did:
Today we saw that SQL server RAM utilization was at 94%.
I then checked Enterprise Auditor for any running jobs or tasks - but there were no instances of running jobs in Enterprise Auditor console.
Also, the Enterprise Auditor logs were investigated and they did not indicate any actively running tasks.
We also checked if there are any active connections to SQL server by opening SSMS and running this query:
Result showed us that the only active connection was the one we created using SQL Server Management Studio.
Since Netwrix Enterprise Auditor was not actively running any tasks - it was suggested to ask for assistance from database administrator from your team.

As we discussed with database administrator  - it is expected from Microsoft SQL Server to keep allocated memory even if the task that required this RAM is not running anymore. This is because Microsoft SQL server uses allocated RAM as a buffer to improve server performance.
As such, database administrator suggested adding a cap for SQL server to keep RAM utilization under 90%.
A cap for 30 GB of RAM was added by changing this setting using SSMS: Database Instance > Properties > Memory > Server memory options settings.
I will proceed with closing of this ticket, but you can always re-open the case if any related issues return.
In addition, you will also receive a separate email with a survey where you can let us know how we did. Feel free to leave any feedback via the survey link!
